summary:
The most important development today was former President Donald Trump unveiling a Gaza peace plan that he says would immediately end the war, boost aid to Gaza, and pressure Hamas to release hostages; his claim that it would immediately end the war is contested and depends on acceptance by regional and Israeli leaders (NPR). Leaders in the Middle East and Europe publicly welcomed the proposal, while Trump warned that if Hamas rejects it the United States will back Israel to "finish the job" of destroying the threat (BBC). The near-term step is diplomatic outreach to secure leader endorsement and negotiations with Palestinian representatives; if Hamas refuses, the plan could increase the risk of expanded military action with U.S. support.

Other news clustered around security, governance, environment and science. Police in Michigan say all victims were accounted for after a church shooting that killed four and the suspect was killed in a police shootout (NPR), closing that local public-safety incident. YouTube agreed to pay $24 million to settle lawsuits over January 6 suspensions, a resolution that could influence platform moderation and political-speech litigation (NPR). Somalia plans its first oil drilling in coming months, a potential economic turning point markets and investors will watch. NASA and SpaceX launched a replacement crew to the ISS so two astronauts can return, and Namibia deployed soldiers to fight a wildfire burning roughly a third of Etosha, threatening wildlife and tourism.

headlines.title: Trump announces Gaza peace plan to end war and boost aid
headlines.summary: Trump says the White House's peace plan would immediately end Gaza war, boost aid, and push Hamas to release hostages, signaling a potential pathway if leaders back it.

headlines.title: Leaders welcome Trump's Gaza peace plan in Middle East and Europe
headlines.summary: Trump says if Hamas rejects the plan, Israel will have US backing to finish the job of destroying the threat, underscoring U.S. commitment as negotiations proceed.

headlines.title: Police say all victims accounted for after Michigan church attack
headlines.summary: Police say everyone has been accounted for after the shooting that killed four at a Michigan church; investigators confirm the suspect was killed in a police shootout.

headlines.title: Somalia begins first oil drilling signaling new economic chapter
headlines.summary: Somalia plans its first oil drilling in coming months, signaling a potential turning point for its economy and energy sector; authorities aim to attract investment and boost growth.

headlines.title: NASA and SpaceX launch crew to space station to retrieve astronauts
headlines.summary: NASA says the replacement Crew-10 takes astronauts to the ISS, enabling the return of Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams after a nine-month stay.

headlines.title: North Korea vows never to give up its nuclear weapons at UNGA
headlines.summary: North Korea says it will never give up its nuclear weapons at the United Nations General Assembly, while leaving doors open to diplomacy.

headlines.title: Namibia deploys army to fight wildfire burning a third of Etosha
headlines.summary: Officials say hundreds of soldiers have begun deploying to fight a wildfire burning a third of Etosha, threatening wildlife and tourism.

headlines.title: YouTube pays Trump $24 million to settle Jan. 6 lawsuit
headlines.summary: YouTube says the settlement of $24 million resolves lawsuits tied to Trump's suspensions and allocates funds for a White House ballroom.
